--- title: "AZ-900 Exam Flashcards" description: "R code to create a flashcard presentation" date: "2021-12-20" categories: [R, Azure] image: "test_1_960x700.png" execute: eval: false --- I recently passed the [AZ-900: Microsoft Azure Fundamentals](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/learn/certifications/exams/az-900) exam. To help study, I created a set of flashcards using a reveal.js presentation from an Excel file of terms/definitions. The repo is [here](https://github.com/WilliamTylerBradley/az_900), with the presentation found [here](https://williamtylerbradley.github.io/az_900/az_900_flashcards.html#/) The terms come from the official skills measured document for 2021. The R code is pretty simple. To set up the presentation, you’ll need the latest version of the revealjs package (Any version of reveal.js past version 4 should work for the r-stack option.). The following front-matter setup should work fine. You can turn on the shuffle option to shuffle the cards every time the document is re-knitted. ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} --- output: revealjs::revealjs_presentation: incremental: false transition: 'none' background_transition: 'none' slide_level: 1 css: custom.css reveal_options: controls: false slideNumber: false progress: false # shuffle: true # uncomment to randomize cards self_contained: false --- ``` ::: The following code is the only markdown needed. It’ll read in the Excel file and loop through the rows to create the presentation. Each flashcard is a different slide. The term is the first fragment with the definition second because the r-stack places them on top of each other. The data-fragment-index is the same for both, so the term will fade out while the definition fades in on the same click. The line of breaks moves the term up a little. I just think it looks a little better. ````r ```{r results='asis', echo=FALSE} library(readxl) terms <- read_excel(here::here("az 900 Skills.xlsx")) for(i in 1:nrow(terms)) { term <- terms$Term[i] definition <- terms$Definition[i] cat(paste("
\n
\n
", term, "
\n
\n
\n")) cat(paste( "
", definition, "
\n
\n
")) } ``` ```` There are opportunities to color the slides based on the subject area, add additional information in the notes, or filter the terms.
